p.seg: kayâs ayîsiyiniwak mistahi kîh-kitimâkisiwak , oskac ôtêh êh-ayâcik , nama kêkway ohci ki-pakitinikôwisiwak . The people of old were in a piteous state, when first they lived here on earth. The Higher Powers had put them down here with nothing at all.
kîh-mosêskatêwak . They went naked.
nama kêkway ayôwinisah ohc âyâwak ; nama kêkway môhkomân . They had no clothes, no knives.
nayêstaw oskan kîh-omôhkomâniwak . All they had for a knife was a bone.
nama kêkway ohc âyâwak iskotêw . From the beginning they had no fire.
acosis pikoh kîh-ohcih-nipahêwak pisiskiwah , oskanah êh-kikamohtâcik wîpisisiwâhk . With merely an arrow they killed animals, fastening bones to their arrows.
nama kêkway ; kîh-kitimâkisiwak . They had nothing; they were in a piteous state.
kîtahtawê iskotêw kîh-osîhtamâsôwak , ômis êh-tôtahkik ; Presently they made fire for themselves, doing it like this; LB: Unfortunately I did not record the gesture.
êh-kisitêyik , piyisk êkotah kîh-ôtinamwak iskotêw . when it was hot, they got fire from it. LB: Probably {kîh-ohtinamwak}.
piyisk asiniyah êh-pakamahwâcik , ê-wâsaskotêpayiyit , êkotê êkwah kiy-ôhtinamwak iskotêw ayîsiyiniwak . Also they pounded a stone, and when it sent out sparks, from this, too, the people got fire.
êkwah asiskiy kih-otaskihkowak . Their pots and kettles were of earth.

mînah kîh-wâtihkêwak , pahkêkin êh-asiwatâcik , asiniyah êh-kisâpiskiswâcik ; êyakôh ohci wiyâs êh-kîsisahkik . Also, they would dig a hole and put in a hide, and heat some stones; in this way they cooked meat.
êkwah kîtahtawê amiskwayânah kîh-otayôwinisiwak . Then in time they began to have beaver-pelts for their clothes.
kîtahtawê pêyak kîh-pawâtam ê-wîh-kapâyit môniyâw-iyiniwa wâpiski-wiyâsah . Then at one time a certain man dreamt that the Canadian, the White Man, would land here.
âcimôw tâyispîhk ta-kapâyit . He told when they would land.
tâpwê ânwêhtawâw ; âtiht tâpwêhtâk . Truly, he was not given credence; only some believed him.
êkwah êkotê mâmihk ispiciwak , cîkih kihcikamihk . Then they moved their camp out there to the east, close to the great sea.
êkwah wîpac kâ-wih-pê-kapâcik ! itwêw ; “Now the time is close at hand when they will land!” he said;
mâskôc ahpôh mitoni kiyipah , itêw ayîsiyiniwah . “Surely very soon,” he told the people.
tahtoh kîkisêpâ ntaw-ây-itâpiw mâna nipîhk . Every morning he would go and look out upon the water.
kîtahtawê kâ-pêcâpahtahk cîmânah . Then at one time he saw boats coming.
ôtah êh-pê-takohtêyit , sakicihcênitôwak ; atamiskotâtôwak . When the others arrived there, they shook each other by the hand and greeted each other.

cikêmâ êkosi nistam kâ-isih-wâpamât ayîsiyiniw wâpiski-wiyâsah . For, indeed, thus it was that the Indian first saw the Whiteskin. LB on {ayîsiyiniw}: Here unmistakably “Indian”; below {nêhiyaw}: “Cree” (kept in translation) is probably meant in the same way. The proper term {wâpiski-wiyâs}: “white-flesh, white man” alternates with {môniyâw}: “Canadian” (kept in translation).

kahkiyaw kêkway kîh-miyik kit-ôh-pimâtisit : môhkoman , pâskisikan , kit-âpacihtât kahkiyaw kêkway pâskisikêwin . They gave him everything to live by: the knife and the gun and all kinds of ammunition for his use.
êkosi êkotah ohci kiskinôhamawâw kit-êsi-pamihtât pâskisikan . So then he began to be taught how to take care of a gun.
êkotah ohci êkwah ati-miyw-âyâwak ayîsiyiniwak . From that time on the Indians were well off.

kîtahtawê êkotah ohci piyisk atimwah ayâwêwak , êh-otâpahâcik . At a certain time after this they began to have horses to pull their loads. LB on {atimwah}: Properly “dogs”, but often used for {misatim}: “horse”; that this is here the case is shown by the next sentence.
ôtêh pikoh nimitâw ayîsiyiniwak okîh-ayâwâhtawâw kayahtê misatimwah ; And, strangely enough, it was only the people in the south who had horses;
nama wîhkâc ohc âyâwêw ayîsiyiniw nâtakâm k-êtapit . the Indian who dwells in the north from that time to this has never had horses.

kîtahtawêh osâm êkâ kêkway êh-ayâcik mâmoscikêwin , kîtahtawê pêyak nâpêw otawâsimisah êh-nâ-nipahâpâkwêyit , -- Presently, because they had no way of worship, presently a certain man whose children had suffered to the point of death from thirst, --
kayâs êsah nama wîhkâc kêkway ômah askîhk ohcih ohpikin ; for it seems that of old nothing ever grew from the earth;
ahpôh maskosiyah kîh-kîsitêwa , -- only grass ripened, --

êkwah pêyak nâpêw osâm mistahih êh-miywâtisit , kîtahtawê kâ-wîhtamâkot okîsikowah ,
hâw , kik-êtohtahitin itêh kit-ôh-pimâtisiyin . then a certain man who was very good, was told by the dwellers in the sky, “Now I will take you whence you will have your source of life.”
êkwah tâpwê âpihtâ-kîsikâhk itohtayik mayaw êh-nipât ; Then truly he was taken to the place of the noonday sky, even as he slept;
êkotê êh-pawâtahk , wîhtamâkôwisiw nipâkwêsimôwikamik . dreaming of that place, he was told by the Higher Powers of the Sun-Dance Lodge.
êwakoh tahtw-âskiy kita-tôtahkik ayîsiyiniwak kîh-miyâwak . The people were given the annual performance of this rite.
êkwah ispîh kiskinôhamôwâw tânis ta-tôtahk ; And at the same time he was taught how to perform it;
okîsikôwah kîh-kiskinôhamâk . by the dwellers in the sky he was taught.
mâskôc nawac nawac tah-miywâsin kâkikê ta-pakitinamâht ayîsiyiniw ; êwako nitêyihtênân . Surely it would be well, if it were always permitted to the Indian; so we think.
tahkih kêkway kitah-miy-ôhpikin . Crops would always grow well.
namoya maci-kêkway nipâkwêsimôkamik . The Sun-Dance Lodge is not an evil thing.

wiyawâw ,
kahkiyaw kêkway maci-kêkway nêhiyawak maci-mantôwah atoskawêwak , itwêwak ayamihêw-iyiniwak . To be sure, “The Cree perform all kinds of evil things for the Evil Spirit,” say the missionaries. KR: Close-quote missing in book.
namoya niynân nêhiyaw ôtah askihk ohcih kikih-pakitinâw ; On the contrary: the Cree was not put down here on earth with these things;
maci-manitôwah mîna manitôw okosisah namoya ohci kiskêyimêw nêhiyaw ; the Cree has never known and does not know an Evil Spirit or a Son of God;
mînah maci-manitôw k-êsiyîhkâsot namoya nêhiyaw kiskêyimêw . and the Cree does not know him who is called the Evil One.

âtah kita-kîh-tâpwêhtahk nêhiyaw , nawac manitôwah êh-kitimâkêyimikot , êkâ wîhkâc ohtinwah kâ-nipahikot . But rather, well may the Cree believe that the Spirit looks with kindlier pity on him, since he is never killed by winds.
nama wîhkâc nêhiyaw nipahik yôtin . Never is a Cree killed by wind.
nama wîhkâc nipahik nêhiyaw piyêsiwah . Never is a Cree killed by the Thunderers.
nama wîhkâc nêhiyaw nipahik iskotêw . Never is a Cree killed by fire.
êkotah ohcih ntêyihtênân , nawac nêhiyaw êh-kitimâkinâkôwisit . That is why we think that the Cree is favored by the Higher Powers.

mâskôc êh-kisiwahât manitôwah , nipâkwêsimôkamik êh-kipihtinahk , êwak ôhci mâh-mistahi k-ôh-pikonahkik môniyaw-ôtênawa , nitêyihtênân ; mîn îskotêw tahto-kiskâw k-ôh-pîkonahk wâskahikanah ; Perhaps it is because he has angered the Spirit by putting a stop to the Sun-Dance Lodge, that in such numbers they break up the Canadian's towns; so we think; and that every day fire destroys the wooden houses; LB on {k-ôh-pikonahkik}: The actor “they” probably refers to the Thunderers.
tahto-kîsikâw misiwê nikiskêyihtênân ê-saskitêkih wâskahikanah , mayaw ôtênâhk êtohtêyâhkoh . every day we learn that everywhere houses have caught fire, every time we go to town.
mîna nipêhtênân tahto-nîpin êh-pîkwâstahkih pikw îtê ôtênawa . And every summer we hear that in many places towns have been destroyed by windstorms.

namoya maci-kêkway kâ-kîh-miyikoyâhk manitôw , mawimoscikêwinah , nayêstaw kit-si-nitotamihk miyo-kêkway . It is not an evil thing which the Spirit has given to us, but ways of worship, only that good things may be prayed for.
êkosi nkîh-isih-pakitinikonân manitôw ôtah askîhk kâ-nêhiyawiyâhk . Thus did the Spirit set us down here on earth, us who are Cree.

âtiht mâmaskâc mastaw êh-ihtakohkih nîmihitôwinah êkâ êh-kipihtinahk wâpiski-wiyâs , nanâtohk êy-isih-mêstinikêhk ; mâka nipâkwêsimôwin nama kêkway mêstinikâniwa . Strange, that some dances which arose much later are not stopped by the White Man, dances in which various things are used up, while the Sun-Dance involves no waste.

nêhiyawak êkotah tahtw-âskiy kîh-miyâwak nîso-kîsikâw êkâh kita-mîcisocik , kita-ntotahkik kahkiyaw kêkway kita-miy-ôhpikiniyik , kita-ntotahkik ta-kimiwaniyik . It was given to the Cree, every year, for two days to go without eating, and to pray that all things might grow well, and to pray for rain.
êkosi kâh-isi-pakitiniht ôt âskîhk kitimâkayîsiyiniw . It was thus that the poor Indian was set down here on earth.
nika-miywêyihtên niya mîna wâhyaw kit-êtohtêmakahk pîkiskwêwin , êkâ êh-wâpiyan . I too shall be glad to have my speech go far abroad, I who am blind.
êkosi aspin êh-ohciyân namoya niwâpin . For from the time I was born, I have been blind.
nama wîhkâc askiy niwâpahtên . Never have I seen the earth.
êkosi âskaw pikw îtê êh-itohtêyân nititohtân ; nama wîhkâc niwanihon . Yet when from time to time I mean to go anywhere, I go there; I never get lost.
êkosi êyôkô pêyak âcimôwin êwako . So much for this, for this one story.
